channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: This middle school’s battle against cellphones yielded surprising results
item.description: Illing Middle School in Manchester, Conn., navigated objections from students and some parents to lock up cellphones in a bid to improve focus and reduce social media-fueled conflicts. What unfolded reflects a broader struggle underway in education as some administrators turn to increasingly drastic measures to limit the reach of a technology that is both ubiquitous and endlessly distracting.

item.title: House passes divisive antisemitism bill as Republicans seek to crack down on campus protests over Gaza war
item.description: Critics of the Antisemitism Awareness Act, which has some Democratic support, call the legislation an effort to silence opinions of Israel and an affront to the First Amendment. It’s unclear what the bill’s prospects are in the Democratic-controlled Senate.

item.title: GOP-led Arizona Senate votes to repeal Civil War-era abortion ban. The Democratic governor is expected to sign it into law.
item.description: The state’s highest court revived the ban on nearly all abortions in early April and it was set to take effect in June. The repeal is expected to be signed into law by Gov. Katie Hobbs in the coming days, but the state attorney general’s office said the repeal would not take effect until 90 days after the legislature adjourns for the summer. So, barring successful court challenges, the 1864 ban could take effect for a short time in the state.

item.title: Federal Reserve leaves interest rates unchanged as rising inflation reduces pressure for cuts
item.description: Since the start of the year, hotter-than-expected price data has complicated officials’ plans for taking pressure off the economy.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Too late to accept a decade-old apology, accidentally left unread?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Too late to accept a decade-old apology, accidentally left unread?

item.title: Live chat: Can a restaurant charge us $900 two months before dinner? Our food critic responds and answers your questions.
item.description: Live chat: Can a restaurant charge us $900 two months before dinner? Our food critic responds and answers your questions.

item.title: A landmark study scared women away from menopause hormone treatments. A 20-year follow-up has found fears were largely overblown.
item.description: A new analysis published in JAMA found that for many younger menopausal women — typically those under 60 — the benefits of the drugs probably outweigh the risks for the short-term treatment of menopause symptoms. The analysis shows that younger women starting menopause and experiencing symptoms can take hormone treatments for several years with a lower likelihood of adverse effects.

item.title: Despair at Florida clinic as 6-week abortion ban — expected to be the biggest jolt to access since Dobbs — takes effect
item.description: At one Fort Lauderdale-area abortion clinic, women crowded the waiting room in the final hours Tuesday before the ban took effect. More than 80,000 women get an abortion in Florida in a typical year, accounting for about 1 in 12 abortions nationwide.

item.title: About 300 protesters were arrested at Columbia University and City College overnight, NYC Mayor Eric Adams says
item.description: Officers in riot gear on Tuesday night cleared Hamilton Hall on Columbia’s campus, which was occupied by pro-Palestinian protesters, as demonstrators and authorities continue to face off on campuses across the nation.

item.title: A baffling artifact in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene says she will move to oust Speaker Mike Johnson. The House is likely to consider the motion next week.
item.description: The move came after weeks of threats from Greene (R-Ga.), angry that Johnson (R-La.) has worked with Democrats to pass key legislation.

item.title: Columbia arrests. Trump penalty. Florida abortion ban. Marijuana. Debt relief. Student phones. Roman mystery. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: New York police enter Columbia University after pro-Palestinian demonstrators occupied a campus building. Follow our live coverage.
item.description: Officers wearing riot gear were holding zip ties on their way to the encampment where students were demanding that the Ivy League university divest from Israeli-linked companies more than six months into that country's war with Hamas.

item.title: Federal judges strike down Louisiana's new congressional map, saying second majority Black district is unconstitutional
item.description: The panel ruled Tuesday that a newly redrawn congressional map, which added a second majority Black district, violated the Equal Protection Clause and blocked the state from using the map in upcoming elections. The Louisiana legislature approved the new map in January after a federal court found that the existing map probably illegally diminished Black voting power.

item.title: A hidden force supercharged this Alabama flood — and threatens the American South
item.description: The U.S. Southeast and Gulf coasts are experiencing one of the world’s worst bursts of sea level rise, turning some storms into flooding disasters, a Washington Post analysis found.

item.title: Are most Americans getting more sleep than you? See how you compare.
item.description: Americans gained 10 minutes of sleep per day, on average, between 2019 and 2022, but that extra time was not evenly shared. The biggest sleep gains were seen in younger adults between the ages of 25 and 34, men of all ages and people without children, according to a Post analysis of data from the American Time Use Survey.

item.title: DEA plans to reclassify marijuana as a lower-risk drug, officials say — a major move that would ease access nationwide
item.description: The move by the Drug Enforcement Administration, first reported by the Associated Press, must receive approval from the White House Office of Management and Budget. Such a decision would not legalize marijuana at the federal level but could broaden access for medicinal use and boost the cannabis industry in states where the drug is legal.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Her family left all the kitchen work to her, so she went on strike
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Her family left all the kitchen work to her, so she went on strike

item.title: Israeli forces killed World Central Kitchen aid workers in Gaza. Here’s why we’re going back, chef José Andrés writes.
item.description: We’re going back to Gaza to feed people. Here’s what we need from Israel.

item.title: Judge in Trump’s N.Y. hush money trial finds the former president in contempt for his critical public statements
item.description: Prosecutors had asked New York Supreme Court Justice Juan Merchan to find former president Donald Trump in contempt for his public statements. Trump was under a gag order after being openly critical of various people — including Merchan’s adult daughter — on the campaign trail and on social media.

item.title: Rachel McAdams, Jeremy Strong and Jessica Lange are among the 2024 Tony nominees. Here is the full list.
item.description: “Hell’s Kitchen,” “Illinoise,” “The Outsiders,” “Suffs” and “Water for Elephants” will contend for best musical at the June 16 ceremony in New York.

item.title: A letter, and no resignation, in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: EPA bans most uses of a toxic paint stripper tied to dozens of deaths
item.description: The move bolsters the Biden administration’s broader crackdown on an array of chemicals known to cause serious health effects, despite their helpful applications in everyday life. Methylene chloride is suspected of causing cancer and has been linked to at least 88 accidental deaths since 1980.

item.title: Columbia protest. Charlotte shooting. Trump trial. Gender care. Emergency brakes. Postpartum depression. Sleep. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Columbia students occupy a university building as tensions continue to rise on campuses across the country
item.description: Student protesters at Columbia University declared overnight that they had taken over a building near the campus’s South Lawn, hours after the Ivy League institution started suspending students who refused to leave a pro-Palestinian encampment on campus. At the University of Texas at Austin, police in riot gear arrested and pepper-sprayed protesters Monday afternoon.

item.title: All new cars must have automatic emergency braking systems by 2029 under new federal safety rule
item.description: The standards require cars to apply brakes automatically to avoid hitting pedestrians and other vehicles, even at higher speeds. Industry groups say the rule is impractical and that no currently produced vehicles can achieve the new standard.

item.title: 3 officers fatally shot, 5 injured while serving warrant in Charlotte, N.C.
item.description: Members of a U.S. Marshals fugitive task force were met with gunfire while trying to serve a warrant. The shooter was also killed, police said.

item.title: The real Rick Steves is so much more complex than the travel host you see on TV
item.description: At 68, America's favorite travel expert is still working hard and speaking out on ways to make the country a little more like his beloved Europe.

item.title: Donald Trump on trial: Personal anguish, political defiance and a loss of control
item.description: Two weeks in, the first criminal trial of a former president has been personally taxing for Donald Trump and disruptive to his campaign for a return to the White House. The indictments that once helped Trump lock down the GOP nomination by firing up his base have become a serious constraint in the general election.

item.title: Federal appellate court rules state health-care plans must pay for gender-affirming surgeries, a major win for transgender rights
item.description: The decision came from a set of cases out of North Carolina and West Virginia, where state officials argued that their policies were based on cost concerns rather than bias. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit rejected that argument, saying the plans were discriminating against trans people in need of treatment.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Is checking his phone the best way to prove he isn’t lying anymore?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Is checking his phone the best way to prove he isn’t lying anymore?

item.title: All about open seating in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Indian intelligence officer directed plot to kill Modi critic on U.S. soil, stunning Western officials, Post investigation finds
item.description: The Post has identified an officer in India’s intelligence service who directed a murder-for-hire scheme to kill a Sikh activist in New York. Higher-ranking officials in the Indian service have also been implicated, according to current and former Western security officials, as part of a sprawling investigation by the CIA, FBI and other agencies.

item.title: College protests. World Central Kitchen. Tornadoes. Tesla lawsuits. Sea level rise. Low birthrates. Vegan cheese. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: My mom won’t vent her frustrations to my dad. So she dumps them on me.
item.description: Ask Sahaj: My mom won’t vent her frustrations to my dad. So she dumps them on me.

item.title: A homeless woman got an apartment in an upscale D.C. building. Conflicts with neighbors and eviction notices ensued.
item.description: In 2021, Staci Jameson had been living in a tent when she received a housing voucher for a one-bedroom apartment downtown. Soon after, she began clashing with neighbors and building management. Her case illustrates the myriad challenges that come after unhoused people are given a place to live, as well as the mental health and other support that is often needed to help them succeed.

item.title: New details from lawsuits test Tesla’s claim that drivers are solely responsible for Autopilot crashes
item.description: The Washington Post obtained dash-cam footage of Tesla crashes that offers sometimes-shocking details of vehicles allegedly on Autopilot. At least eight new lawsuits and a federal investigation contend that Tesla’s technology invites drivers to overly trust the automation.

item.title: Trump met privately with his former rival DeSantis, who agreed to help with campaign fundraising, people familiar say
item.description: Former president Donald Trump and Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis met privately Sunday morning in Miami, breaking a years-long chill between the presumptive Republican nominee and his onetime chief primary rival. The meeting was friendly, according to a person with direct knowledge.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Biden roasted Trump at the White House correspondents’ dinner — but made it clear it was no joke
item.description: Washington’s annual mashup of political humor and earnest paeans to the free press is typically a good-natured collection of one-liners and affectionate jabs at friends and enemies alike. But it was the leading 2024 presidential contenders who loomed largest.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: They bought homes for under $1 million. Here’s what they learned.
item.description: Last year, just over 4 million existing homes sold in the United States — the lowest number in nearly three decades, according to the National Association of Realtors. Nine households that bought real estate in the past year share how they navigated the buying process during these tumultuous times.

item.title: Among the 18 Trump allies indicted in Arizona this week: A senior counsel to the RNC’s election integrity team
item.description: When conservative lawyer and media personality Christina Bobb became the latest member of Donald Trump’s inner circle to be charged for her alleged role in the effort to reverse the 2020 presidential election results, it became immediately clear she would not have to give up her day job with the Republican National Committee. Bobb’s indictment solidifies her identity as a dedicated Trump loyalist and potentially elevates her role within the RNC.

item.title: A vegan cheese beat dairy in a big competition. Then the plot curdled.
item.description: When Climax Foods’ plant-based blue cheese was named as a finalist in the Good Food awards, traditionalists were shaken. Its status was revoked as controversy fomented.

item.title: Looking for something to watch? These are the best new TV shows and series in 2024 so far.
item.description: “Ripley,” “The Sympathizer,” “Shogun,” “Fallout,” “Elsbeth,” “Constellation” and “The Girls on the Bus” all make our critics’ evolving list of the year’s best TV shows.

item.title: Ask Elaine: After a traumatic birth, new mom can’t let go of debilitating fears
item.description: Ask Elaine: After a traumatic birth, new mom can’t let go of debilitating fears

item.title: What happened to a man who threatened Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.): ‘You spread hatred, and you’re gonna pay for it’
item.description: In a time of rising political anger, one man going through a mental health crisis threatened the congresswoman after seeing one of her political ads. Then came the consequences.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Restoring sight is now possible with gene therapy
item.description: Several companies are experimenting with optogenetics to create a “bionic eye” that can restore sight in visually impaired people.

item.title: Asia’s next war could be triggered by a rusting warship on a disputed reef
item.description: In the South China Sea, tensions over competing claims by China and countries in Southeast Asia have grown more intense than at any time in recent years. The risk of armed confrontation increasingly hinges on China’s efforts to block the Philippines from resupplying the crew aboard a dilapidated navy ship intentionally grounded on a contested reef to establish it as a military outpost.
